title: Question 89

children: A 77-year-old woman is evaluated for lightheadedness when assuming an upright posture and two episodes of syncope occurring shortly after arising from bed and after prolonged sitting. She has a 7-year history of diabetic peripheral neuropathy but no other cardiac conditions.
On physical examination, seated blood pressure and pulse rate are normal. The remainder of the general examination is normal.
Which of the following diagnostic tests should be performed next?
Orthostatic blood pressure measurements should be performed in all patients with syncope.

A drop in systolic blood pressure greater than 20 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure greater than 10 mm Hg immediately after standing or after 3 minutes of upright posture is diagnostic of orthostatic hypotension.

A drop in systolic BP greater than 20 mm Hg or diastolic BP greater than 10 mm Hg on immediate standing or after 3 minutes of upright posture is diagnostic of orthostatic hypotension. This patient has diabetes mellitus with peripheral neuropathy and may also have diabetic autonomic neuropathy, which can cause orthostatic hypotension. Other neurodegenerative causes of orthostatic hypotension include amyloidosis, Parkinson disease, and multiple system atrophy. Medications that commonly cause or contribute to orthostatic hypotension include diuretics, Î±-blockers, antihypertensives, and antiparkinson medications.

If the cause of syncope is unclear after the initial evaluation, continuous telemetry may be useful to screen for paroxysmal arrhythmias. If symptoms are frequent, 24-hour monitoring may be used; if symptoms are infrequent, an event monitor (
